title: Give musicians tax holidays to produce music for export – Prof John Collins
text:
Source: Ghana | Myjoyonline.com | Ernest Dela Aglanu (Twitter: @delaXdela / Instagram: citizendela) Date: 23-10-2015 Time: 07:10:59:am 
Music lecturer at the University of Ghana, Prof John Collins has called on the government to give tax holidays to musicians enable them produce music for the international market. 
He noted that government can give tax concessions to Ghanaians musicians just as it does for several other businesses in the country. 
Prof John Collins believes that when this is done, musicians will be motivated to produce good music that can be exported to the market. 
Speaking in an interview on Personality Profile on Joy FM with Lexis Bill Thursday, the music professor revealed it was not until recently that the government came to the realisation that it can make money from music. 
“Up to about ten years ago, there was a super import duty on musical instruments and the government themselves had a blind spot to the role of music – they now call it the Creative Arts – as a money maker so they considered anything to do with music as a luxury and then they [placed] heavy import duties on musical instruments,” he noted. 
Prof Collins recalled that, “It was actually under [Former President] Kufuor that this was reduced so gradually maybe the last five or ten years the government has suddenly woken up to the fact that you can make money from the music industry [and] it’s not just educational reasons or cultural reasons but you can make money for the government.” 
The government is coming around the fact that the music industry/the creative arts is a big money maker just like Nigeria has shown, he added. 
“Nkrumah had a real vision of using the arts for national development,” the music professor recounted and added that, “After Nkrumah was overthrown we went through many years where the arts was sort of relegated to the background and its only been in the past ten years or so that the government has sort of realised that maybe you are not going to use the arts for national development in the way that Nkrumah was but at least [it] can make money for the country.” 
He advised that the government “can export world music for foreign exchange like pineapples. We export pineapples for foreign exchange and we give tax concessions to those companies… they can do the same for musicians. Give them some tax concessions and let them produce good music for the world market.”
